case_title: Fazal-ur-Rehman, JMAQSOOD AHMED vs THE STATE
complaint_summary: The appellant was accused of possessing narcotics, including 8 kg of opium and 4 kg of charas, recovered during a raid on his residence in Killi Kashmirabad, Quetta.
investigation_summary: A police raid led by P.W.2 Rasool Bakhsh, under the supervision of DSP/SDPO, recovered narcotics from the appellant's residence. The narcotics were seized and documented in a recovery memo. Chemical analysis confirmed the substances as opium and charas.
judgment_summary: The court upheld the conviction under section 9(c) of the Control of Narcotic Substances Act, 1997, sentencing the appellant to 14 years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 20,000. The appeal was dismissed, with the court finding no merit in the appellant's claims of false implication.
punishment: 14 years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 20,000, with an additional 6 months simple imprisonment in case of default on fine payment.
legal_arguments: Defense argued non-compliance with section 103, Cr.P.C., and unreliability of police witnesses.
Prosecution countered with section 25 of the Control of Narcotic Substances Act, 1997, which overrides section 103, Cr.P.C.
sections: Section 9(c) of Control of Narcotic Substances Act, 1997
Section 25 of Control of Narcotic Substances Act, 1997
Section 29 of Control of Narcotic Substances Act, 1997

witness_statement.Rasool Bakhsh: Led the raid and documented the recovery of narcotics.
witness_statement.Syed Abdul Jabbar: Confirmed the chemical composition of the seized narcotics.

key_issues: Compliance with procedural requirements under Cr.P.C.

maxims.Burden of Proof: Appellant failed to discharge the burden under section 29 of the Control of Narcotic Substances Act, 1997.

words_and_phrases.Narcotics: Illegal substances such as opium and charas
words_and_phrases.Recovery Memo: Document detailing the seizure of items during a raid

summary_vector_notes: The appellant was convicted for possession of narcotics under section 9(c) of the Control of Narcotic Substances Act, 1997. The court dismissed the appeal, affirming the trial court's judgment and sentence of 14 years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 20,000. The defense's arguments regarding procedural lapses and witness reliability were rejected based on statutory provisions and corroborative evidence.
